009
010package imagingbook.common.noise.perlin;
011
012import imagingbook.common.noise.hashing.Hash32Shift;
013import imagingbook.common.noise.hashing.HashFunction;
014
015/**
016 * <p>
017 * Gradient (Perlin) noise implementation (see [1] for a detailed description).
018 * This is the super-class for all other Perlin noise generators (1D, 2D,
019 * N-dimensional).
020 * </p>
021 * <p>
022 * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Principles of Digital Image Processing &ndash;
023 * Advanced Methods</em> (Vol. 3), Supplementary Chapter 8: "Synthetic Gradient
024 * Noise", Springer (2013). <a href=
025 * "https://dx.doi.org/10.13140/RG.2.1.3427.7284">https://dx.doi.org/10.13140/RG.2.1.3427.7284</a>
026 * </p>
027 * 
028 * @author WB
029 * @version 2022/11/24
030 */
031public abstract class PerlinNoiseGenerator {
032
033        private final double f_min;
034        private final double f_max;
035        private final int oct;
036        private final double persistence; // persistence (phi)
037        
038        final double[] F;               // frequencies f_i
039        final double[] A;               // amplitudes a_i
040        final HashFunction hashFun;
041
042        /**
043         * Constructor (non-public).
044         */
045        PerlinNoiseGenerator(double f_min, double f_max, double persistence, HashFunction hash) {
046                if (f_max < f_min) {
047                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("f_max must not be less than f_min");
048                }
049                this.f_min = f_min;
050                this.f_max = f_max;
051                this.oct = getFrequencySteps(f_min, f_max);
052                this.F = new double[oct];
053                this.A = new double[oct];
054                this.persistence = persistence;
055                this.hashFun = (hash != null) ? hash : new Hash32Shift();       // default
056                this.makeFrequencies(f_min, f_max);
057        }
058
059        /**
060         * Perlin's improved "fading" function s(x)
061         * @param x interpolation position in [0,1]
062         * @return s(x) = 10 x^3 - 15 x^4 + 6 x^5 
063         */
064        double s(double x) {
065                return x * x * x * (x * (x * 6 - 15) + 10);
066        }
067
068        // ----------------- helper methods: ----------------------------
069        
070        private void makeFrequencies(double fmin, double fmax) {
071                int n = 0;
072                double f = f_min;
073                double a = 1;
074                while (f <= f_max && n < oct) {
075                        F[n] = f;
076                        A[n] = a;
077                        n = n + 1;
078                        f = 2 * f;
079                        a = persistence * a;
080                }
081        }
082
083        private int getFrequencySteps(double fmin, double fmax) {       // TODO: should not be public!
084                int i = 0;
085                double f = fmin;
086                while (f <= fmax) {
087                        i = i + 1;
088                        f = 2 * f;
089                }
090                return i;
091        }
092        
093        /**
094         * Fast floor method (by Gustavson?)
095         * @param x argument
096         * @return floor(x), works for pos. and neg. x.
097         */
098        int ffloor(double x) {
099                int xint = (int) x;
100                return (xint < x) ? xint : xint - 1;
101        }
102
103        // -----------------------------------------------
104        
105        /**
106         * @return An array with the frequencies f_i used for generating 
107         * the noise function.
108         */
109        public double[] getFrequencies() {
110                return F;
111        }
112
113        /**
114         * @return An array with the amplitudes a_i used for generating 
115         * the noise function.
116         */
117        public double[] getAmplitudes() {
118                return A;
119        }
120
121}
